elements.name: Hydrogen
elements.reactivity: Highly reactive, burns readily in air
elements.detectionTest: Pop test - produces a 'pop' sound when lit with a splint
elements.description: Lightest element, essential for life, fuel for stars

elements.name: Helium
elements.reactivity: Completely unreactive under normal conditions
elements.detectionTest: Spectroscopic analysis shows characteristic emission lines
elements.description: Second lightest element, noble gas, used in balloons

elements.name: Lithium
elements.reactivity: Very reactive, must be stored in oil
elements.detectionTest: Flame test produces brilliant crimson/red color
elements.description: Lightest metal, used in batteries and mood stabilizers

elements.name: Fluorine
elements.reactivity: Most reactive element, reacts with almost everything
elements.detectionTest: Silver nitrate test after dissolution in water
elements.description: Most electronegative element, used in toothpaste

elements.name: Chlorine
elements.reactivity: Very reactive, less than fluorine but more than bromine
elements.detectionTest: Silver nitrate test produces white precipitate of AgCl
elements.description: Used for water purification and bleaching

elements.name: Bromine
elements.reactivity: Reactive, less than chlorine but more than iodine
elements.detectionTest: Silver nitrate test produces cream precipitate of AgBr
elements.description: Only liquid non-metal at room temperature

elements.name: Iodine
elements.reactivity: Least reactive halogen (excluding astatine)
elements.detectionTest: Silver nitrate test produces yellow precipitate of AgI; Starch test turns blue
elements.description: Essential for thyroid function, sublimes to purple vapor

elements.name: Sodium
elements.reactivity: Highly reactive, stored under oil
elements.detectionTest: Flame test produces bright yellow/orange color
elements.description: Essential electrolyte, main component of table salt

elements.name: Potassium
elements.reactivity: More reactive than sodium, catches fire in air
elements.detectionTest: Flame test produces lilac/violet color
elements.description: Essential for nerve and muscle function

elements.name: Iron
elements.reactivity: Moderately reactive, rusts in presence of oxygen and water
elements.detectionTest: Potassium thiocyanate produces blood-red color for Fe3+
elements.description: Most common element on Earth, essential for blood

elements.name: Beryllium
commonReactions: Be + 2H2O → Be(OH)2 + H2 (Reacts slowly with water)
elements.reactivity: Less reactive than other alkaline earth metals
elements.detectionTest: Forms a complex with ammonia, detected by spectroscopy
elements.description: Toxic light metal, used in aerospace alloys

elements.name: Carbon
elements.reactivity: Varies by allotrope; graphite is reactive, diamond is not
elements.detectionTest: Combustion to CO2 which turns limewater milky
elements.description: Basis of organic chemistry, exists in multiple allotropes

elements.name: Oxygen
elements.reactivity: Very reactive, supports combustion
elements.detectionTest: Glowing splint test - a glowing splint reignites in oxygen
elements.description: Essential for respiration, makes up 21% of atmosphere

elements.name: Magnesium
elements.reactivity: Reactive metal, burns with brilliant white light
elements.detectionTest: Flame test produces bright white light
elements.description: Lightweight structural metal, essential for chlorophyll

elements.name: Calcium
commonReactions: Ca + 2H2O → Ca(OH)2 + H2 (Reacts vigorously with water)
elements.reactivity: Very reactive, reacts readily with water
elements.detectionTest: Flame test produces brick-red color
elements.description: Essential for bones and teeth, used in construction

elements.name: Copper
elements.reactivity: Less reactive than most metals, doesn't react with water
elements.detectionTest: Flame test produces green-blue color; ammonia turns deep blue with Cu2+
elements.description: Excellent electrical conductor, used in wiring

elements.name: Silver
elements.reactivity: Noble metal, resistant to oxidation
elements.detectionTest: Forms white precipitate with chloride ions (AgCl)
elements.description: Precious metal with highest electrical conductivity

elements.name: Gold
commonReactions: No reaction with oxygen or water
elements.reactivity: Extremely unreactive, doesn't tarnish or corrode
elements.detectionTest: Purple of Cassius test with tin chloride
elements.description: Precious metal, valued for jewelry and currency

elements.name: Nitrogen
elements.reactivity: Relatively inert at room temperature due to triple bond
elements.detectionTest: Lassaigne's test - sodium fusion followed by iron(II) sulfate produces Prussian blue
elements.description: Makes up 78% of atmosphere, essential for proteins

elements.name: Sulfur
elements.reactivity: Moderately reactive, forms compounds with most elements
elements.detectionTest: Sodium fusion test followed by lead acetate gives black precipitate of PbS
elements.description: Yellow crystalline solid, used in sulfuric acid production

1.name: Alkali Metals
1.characteristics: Very reactive metals, one electron in outer shell, react violently with water

17.name: Halogens
17.characteristics: Very reactive non-metals, seven electrons in outer shell, form salts with metals

18.name: Noble Gases
18.characteristics: Chemically inert, complete outer electron shells

periodicTrends.atomicRadius: Decreases across period, increases down group
periodicTrends.ionizationEnergy: Increases across period, decreases down group
periodicTrends.electronegativity: Increases across period, decreases down group
periodicTrends.metallicCharacter: Decreases across period, increases down group

1.name: Alkali Metals
1.reactivityTrend: Reactivity increases down the group as atomic radius increases
1.commonProperties: Soft, silvery metals with low melting points, very reactive with water

2.name: Alkaline Earth Metals
2.reactivityTrend: Reactivity increases down the group but less reactive than Group 1
2.commonProperties: Silvery metals, harder than alkali metals, react with water

17.name: Halogens
17.reactivityTrend: Reactivity decreases down the group as atomic radius increases
17.commonProperties: Highly reactive non-metals, form salts with metals, exist as diatomic molecules

18.name: Noble Gases
18.reactivityTrend: Generally unreactive at standard conditions, but reactivity increases down the group
18.commonProperties: Colorless, odorless gases, complete outer electron shells

flameTest.description: Flame tests are used to identify certain metals. The sample is put into a flame and the color observed.

precipitationTest.description: Adding specific reagents to solutions containing ions can form characteristic precipitates.

organicElementTests.description: Tests to identify elements in organic compounds.

examples.Carbon: Combustion forms CO2 which turns limewater milky
examples.Hydrogen: Combustion forms H2O which condenses on cool surface
examples.Nitrogen: Lassaigne's test - sodium fusion followed by iron(II) sulfate gives Prussian blue
examples.Sulfur: Sodium fusion test followed by lead acetate gives black precipitate
examples.Halogens: Sodium fusion test followed by silver nitrate gives precipitate

combination.description: Two or more substances combine to form a single product.

decomposition.description: A single compound breaks down into multiple simpler substances.
examples: 2H2O → 2H2 + O2 (Water decomposing into hydrogen and oxygen)

singleDisplacement.description: An element replaces another element in a compound.
examples: Zn + CuSO4 → ZnSO4 + Cu (Zinc displacing copper)

doubleDisplacement.description: The positive and negative ions of two compounds exchange places.
examples: AgNO3 + NaCl → AgCl + NaNO3 (Silver nitrate and sodium chloride)
BaCl2 + Na2SO4 → BaSO4 + 2NaCl (Barium chloride and sodium sulfate)

combustion.description: A substance combines with oxygen, releasing energy as heat and light.
